sen.e: Although the position of the tea master was passed to Sosen Shinjo, a deputy of the chief abbot of Myoshin-ji Temple, and then to Reijo Jinpo, subsequently moving to Ise City with her; however, the practices of the tea ceremony of the school were frequently performed in Keijo, and because of the end of the World War II, the school was evacuated from Keijo.

sen.j: 柄杓・蓋置・建水を運び出す時に、全てを建水に仕組むのが一般的である。
sen.e: While it is a general preparation for tea ceremony that water utensils are arranged in the way the host would bring them into the tearoom; thus a hishaku (a ladle) rests in a kensui (a waste-water container (for tea ceremony)) and inside is a hutaoki (a rest for the lid of a tea kettle), it is the preparation of the Juko school's style that the host enters the tearoom, bringing in a hishaku and a hutaoki with his right hand and only kensui with his left hand in the same way to take these utensils from the tearoom after the tea ceremony is over.
sen.cmt: 仕組む→準備する→全てを建水に仕組む→具体的に、"a hishaku rests on a kensui and inside is a hutaoki"と訳出し/ 仕舞い→かたずける→"to take these utensils from the tea room after the tea ceremony is over"と訳出しました。

sen.j: 元禄期津軽藩の茶道役野本道玄の「珠光流聞書」には珠光の弟子である一樹庵光玉を流祖とする系図が示されているが、ほぼ同時期の宗匠である鈴木備長庵による「茶道珠光流系譜」によれば流祖は村田珠光であり備長庵は7代にあたるとされる。
sen.e: Although "Juko-ryu kikigaki (dictation of oral narrative, or interview report about the Juko school)" shows the family tree whose founder was Kogyoku Ichijuan, one of the disciples of Juko, written by Dogen NOMOTO, who was a chabozu of the Tugaru domain (a tea-server sustaining Japanese tea ceremony of bakufu and domains) during the Genroku period, "Sado Juko-ryu Keifu (family tree of the Juko school of tea ceremony)" written by Bichoan SUZUKI, the tea master of almost the same period as Dogen NOMOTO, reads that the founder of the Juko school was Juko MURATA and the seventh-generation head of the school was Bichoan SUZUKI.
